EditInstructions.*: Content-Groups are a fundamental part of 2sxc - they contain the definition of a set of selected items and how they should be displayed. You should almost never edit this - for more information read about it in the wiki.

Notes.*: This is a refernce to the view - internally it's called Template.
This was previously called ListContent - but that was confusing.
This was previously called ListPresentation, but this was confusing.

Description.*: A pointer / reference to a content group

EditInstructions.*: A reference to a content-group. As the target group/block could be inside another app, all fields are simple string fields, because they can't enforce that the target exists. See also what the wiki says about this.
Templates / Views determine how output is shown. This dialog helps you configure what file is used, what data it expects and more. See View docs for more.

DeleteWarning.en-us: If you remove this, this view will not be the default any more.

Notes.*: just a nice name which will be shown in dropdowns and similar

The template is a html or code file, which is will generate the output. It could be simple HTML showing a decorative line, a token-based HTML with placeholders like [Content:Title], or an advanced c# Razor template with placeholders like @Content.Title as well as conditions, loops etc.
this type determines which view-engine will be used to render the result

Notes.en-us: templates are usually stored in the portal - or in rare cases or in the shared, default-zone - note that sharing templates has various caveats, so you should read about shared templates here

DropdownValues.en-us:
Site:App Files in the Current Site
Global:App Files in Shared (Global) section 🤝

Notes.*: choose or create the template file - more help

Notes.en-us: Determine how the icon (if any) is provided. See docs.

TitleFalse.en-us: Icon uses the same-named file in the template folder or a default symbol

Notes.en-us: We recommend using the [App:Path] placeholder - see docs.

Placeholder.en-us: Drop file or use [App:Path]/filename.png for files in your app-folder

Notes.*:
Views are visible and selectable by default. Here you can change how this behaves. Some reasons you may want to do this:

  1. If your view is only needed on one page and then shouldn't be available any more (because it's an admin view or something) then you want to add it to that page and then configure to Hide from Editor.
  2. If your view is a details-view (so another list has a link which will show this, then...
    1. You want to specify that it only shows if a term is in the URL
    2. And you probably want to also hide it, so editors don't choose this view to add to a page directly.
hide this template from the normal selection - this is for templates you only want to insert once or twice, and then prevent additional uses

specify this if you want this template to be activated automatically, when some keywords appear in the url - like showing details when /post/395 is in the path (note: this only works in Apps) - read more
This shows/hides various settings based on what you need.

DropdownValues.*:
Please choose...:
View doesn't need Data:-
Single Content Item:c
List of Content Items:cl
Data from Query:q
Data from Query with Module-Content:cq
Show all Settings:clq

Notes.*: Content-items can have a Presentation item to describe how it should be styled when shown on a specific Module instance.
Templates show either Content, Data, both, or neither. If you're just getting started, Content is the way to go. Read more about this in the online help.
the type of content this template will show - like a person, simple content, etc.
this item will be used for previews, so the user can see what the template does without entering any data

Notes.en-us: Presentation settings are used to configure how your content will be shown. You can do very sophisticated things with this. Read more about it in help.

Placeholder.*: Content-Type which is used for presentation-settings

Notes.*: this will contain a demo entity which is used as a default (when the editor doesn't provide custom presentation settings) as well as for preview - when the template is just showing the demo-item to the editor - more

You can create templates which show multiple items - like a list of links or images. enable this here to tell the edit-UI, that this template can show more than just 1 item - so this will provide more buttons like add, move-up/down, etc. - more
turn this on, to tell the UI that this template handles lists
this is the content-type for the Header item in a list-template - more
the default / demo-item for the list Header item - more

Name.*: Content Type of the Header Presentation

Notes.*: Configure presentation settings of the list Header - read more about lists or presentation settings

Name.*: Demo Item for the Header Presentation

Notes.*: the default/demo item for list presentations - more about presentation settings

A template instance can work with Content, Data, both or neither. Here you can configure the system to provide pre-processed data to the template. more

Important: queries can only be used in views of an App. They are not available for normal Content. more
a prepared query which will provide data to this template - more

Notes.en-us: If the platform like DNN has built-in search, it will find the data shown on this view point to the page this view is on. There are cases where you may want to customize this. See docs.

TitleTrue.*: Default Search Indexing (all Module-Data is given to the Search Index)
Disable Search Index (will not give data to the search indexer)

TitleFalse.*: Pass all Query-Streams to the Search Index (default)

TitleTrue.*: Restrict which Streams in the Query are passed to the Search Index

Name.*: Query Streams to Use in the Search Index

TitleTrue.*: Use Code to Customize how Data is Modified

Title.en-us: View Configuration - ViewController (Search) - Provide Settings for Type/Location Masks

Name.en-us: Advanced Data Publishing Settings (Old, Deprecated, Avoid using)

Notes.en-us: This is a deprecated feature. If you need something similar or are migrating away, check out the guide on https://r.2sxc.org/brc-13-id
enables instances of this view to provide the data it would render on the server as JSON - more about templates and more about publishing JSON data
if you choose to publish data, you must specify which streams you will publish for security reasons - more
Settings allow your Razor templates to be configured at View-level, or you can also use the Identifier for this. Resources are for multi-language labels and logos. See View docs.

TitleTrue.*: Use a Custom Identifier for this View

Notes.*: This is a unique ID for the view, which your code may access on CmsContext.View.Identifier to change it's behaviour based on this identifier. Usually you will either use this OR use the settings.

Placeholder.*: Templates can change their behavior based on this Identifier

EditInstructions.en-us:
BETA / EXPERIMENTAL - Configure Open-Graph Data for this Page/Object

As of right now it can only specify the type and title. In future, we'll add a lot of fields and also add merging OpenGraph values with other OpenGraph values added by content.
